news_article: US researchers found that the COVID-19 pandemic may affect infants' brains. The study, conducted when the babies were six months old, observed that those born during the pandemic found it hard to manage certain tasks linked to muscle movements and personal interactions. The scientists studied 255 infants born during the pandemic including 114 whose mothers had COVID-19 during pregnancy.

news_headline: NASA launches 4th mission to study origin of soft X-rays in space
news_article: NASA launched the fourth Diffuse X-rays from the Local galaxy or DXL mission on January 9 from the Wallops Flight Facility in Virginia. The mission will study the origin of soft X-rays in the galaxy that impact technology in Earth's atmosphere. The mission's Principal Investigator said that X-rays from space come from two sources, outside and within the solar system.

news_headline: Heart disease-linked risks may be worse for women than men: US study
news_article: US neurologists found greater negative impact of cardiovascular diseases such as diabetes, heart disease on memory skills of middle-aged women than men. Through nine different kinds of tests, the researchers observed that heart disease was associated with a decline in composite cognitive test scores for women compared to men. The study tested over 1,000 people aged 50 to 69.

news_headline: US sees record COVID-19 hospitalisations as record 11 lakh test positive
news_article: COVID-19 hospitalisations in the US reached a record high on Monday at 1,32,646 amid Omicron, according to Reuters. The United States reported at least 11.3 lakh new coronavirus infections on Monday, the highest daily total of any country in the world, Reuters said. Hospitalisations in the US have increased steadily since late December, doubling in the last three weeks.

news_headline: Protestors throw seaweed, stones at French MP over COVID-19 vaccine pass
news_article: Protestors opposing a bill on COVID-19 vaccine pass, threw seaweed, dirt and stones at French MP Stéphane Claireaux, outside his home. A video of the incident has also surfaced on social media. The French government is seeking to pass a law that would require residents to show proof of their vaccination to access public venues and transport.

news_headline: Man in US gets genetically-modified pig heart in world-first transplant
news_article: David Bennett, a 57-year-old US man, has become the first person in the world to get a heart transplant from a genetically-modified pig. Bennett is doing well three days after the experimental seven-hour procedure in Baltimore, doctors said. Doctors had deemed him ineligible for a human transplant due to very poor health.

news_headline: Video shows mother throwing baby into dumpster in US; says 'Didn't know what to do'
news_article: An 18-year-old mother was caught on surveillance footage throwing her newborn baby alive into a dumpster in US' New Mexico. Alexis Avila told investigators she didn't know she was pregnant until January 6, when she sought medical attention because she was suffering from abdominal pain. She said she "panicked and did not know what to do or who to call".

news_headline: UC Berkeley professor Pierre-Olivier succeeds Gita Gopinath as IMF Chief Economist
news_article: The IMF has appointed Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas as its next Chief Economist, succeeding India-born Gita Gopinath. Gourinchas is the University of California at Berkeley's Faculty Director of the Clausen Center for International Business and Policy. He will start his new position on January 24 part-time and transition to full-time on April 1. Gopinath will become IMF's First Deputy MD.

news_headline: Police officers ignore active robbery to catch Snorlax in Pokemon Go in US
news_article: Two police officers in US' Los Angeles were fired for ignoring a robbery in progress and instead trying to catch a Snorlax in Pokemon Go, according to court documents published on Friday. The incident happened in April, 2017, at a mall. The police officers were in the area but didn't respond to the call and instead drove away.

news_headline: Robert Durst, US multi-millionaire real estate heir convicted of murder, dies at 78
news_article: Multi-millionaire real estate heir Robert Durst, who was sentenced to life in prison in October for murdering his best friend, has died at 78 in a California prison hospital, according to his attorney. He was also charged with murder of his first wife Kathleen Durst, who disappeared in 1982. Robert Durst was the subject of a 2015 HBO documentary series.

news_headline: Do not travel to Canada: US to citizens over COVID-19 surge
news_article: The US on Monday advised its citizens to "avoid travel" to Canada because of a rising number of COVID-19 cases in the neighbouring country. Canadian health officials on Friday had said that new daily cases had soared by 65% in the previous week, threatening healthcare systems. Canada is facing a COVID-19 surge due to the highly transmissible Omicron variant.

news_headline: Sweden to tighten COVID-19 curbs amid rising infections: PM
news_article: Sweden will introduce new curbs to limit COVID-19 spread amid a "historically high level" of infections, PM Magdalena Andersson said on Monday. Sweden, which reported 60,000 COVID-19 cases last week, will from Wednesday onwards not allow restaurants to seat groups larger than eight people. Public events with over 50 people will be permitted if attendees can provide proof of vaccination.

news_headline: Mexican Prez tests COVID-19 +ve for 2nd time, says symptoms are 'mild'
news_article: Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador said he has tested positive for coronavirus for the second time, but his symptoms are "mild". The 68-year-old, who rarely wears a face mask, got tested after he'd sounded hoarse at a Monday morning news briefing. "I'll remain isolated and only work from the office and hold online meetings until further notice," he added.

news_headline: We have enough vaccines for all Canadians to get 4th dose: Trudeau
news_article: Canadian PM Justin Trudeau said the government has secured enough COVID-19 vaccine doses for all eligible Canadians to receive a booster as well as a fourth dose. This comes as the country grapples with rising infection and hospitalisation rates due to the Omicron variant. More than 87% of Canadians aged 12 and older have received two COVID-19 vaccine doses.

news_headline: China halts some US flights after COVID-19 cases among arrivals
news_article: China has ordered the cancellation of over two dozen scheduled flights from US in recent weeks after numerous passengers arriving in the country tested COVID-19 positive. A US-China air agreement allows the countries to operate over 100 weekly flights between the nations, but currently, only a fraction of those are operating. The US has reported over 6.1 crore COVID-19 cases.

news_headline: Looking forward to stabilisation of situation: India on Kazakhstan
news_article: Speaking about the recent developments in Kazakhstan, the Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) on Monday said that it's looking "forward to an early stabilisation of the situation". "We express our deepest condolences to families of innocent victims who have lost lives in the violence," it added. Kazakhstan authorities on Sunday said that 164 people were killed in last week's protests.

news_headline: Myanmar military govt accuses US diplomats of COVID rules violation
news_article: The military government in Myanmar has accused US diplomats of breaking coronavirus-related rules of the country. The government said that two US diplomats were allowed to receive treatment for COVID-19 at properties of the American embassy without any permission from local authorities. This was done despite the embassy being informed to admit the patients to designated hospitals, it added.

news_headline: European Parliament President David Sassoli dies aged 65
news_article: European Parliament President David Sassoli has died at the age of 65, his spokesman said. He was admitted to hospital in Italy last month due to a "serious complication" with his immune system. Sassoli left a three-decade career in journalism and became a member of the European Parliament in 2009. He was elected as the European Parliament President in 2019.

news_headline: Israel not bound by any nuclear deal with Iran: PM Naftali Bennett
news_article: Israeli PM Naftali Bennett said on Monday that Israel isn't bound by any nuclear deal with Iran and is free to act without “constraints" against Iran if necessary. PM Bennett’s comments come amid indirect talks between US and Iran to restart the stalled 2015 Iran nuclear deal. Israel had condemned this deal and views a nuclear-armed Iran as existential threat.

news_headline: Iran Foreign Minister to discuss cooperation agreement with China
news_article: The Iranian Foreign Ministry said that the Foreign Minister, Hossein Amirabdollahian, will visit China by the end of this week to discuss the 25-year cooperation agreement along with various issues. The two countries signed the comprehensive strategic partnership agreement to strengthen their economic and political alliance in March 2021. This comes after both were subjected to US sanctions.

news_headline: 72-year-old US man arrested for threatening to kidnap, kill Trump
news_article: A 72-year-old US man has been arrested and charged with allegedly threatening to kidnap and kill ex-President Donald Trump, a criminal indictment showed. Thomas Welnicki, who made a series of threats between July 2020 and December 2021, had at least once referred to Trump as "Hitler" and said he would do "everything" he can to make sure Trump was killed.

news_headline: Iraq's new Parliament elects Speaker months after national election
news_article: The new Parliament in Iraq elected Sunni lawmaker, Mohammed al-Halbousi as the Speaker on Sunday, three months after the national election. The incumbent speaker, Halbousi won after securing 200 votes in the 329-seat house defeating acting Speaker Mahmoud al-Mashahadani. This comes after the Parliament observed heated debates from parties over leadership of the house.

news_headline: Kazakhstan govt blames Islamic radicals for unrest, detains 8,000
news_article: Kazakhstan Foreign Ministry on Monday said that the country was subjected to armed aggression by radical Islamist groups. The ministry added that the government detained nearly 8,000 people to control the situation. This comes after government buildings and security forces were attacked last week after peaceful protests over fuel price hike turned into violent anti-government demonstrations.

news_headline: North Korea fires 2nd suspected missile in less than a week
news_article: South Korea and Japan on Tuesday said North Korea has fired a "suspected ballistic missile", less than a week after it launched what it claimed was a hypersonic missile. South Korea's National Security Council held an emergency meeting and expressed "strong regret" over the test. The launch comes after six countries, including US, urged North Korea to end "destabilising actions".

news_headline: Nearly 10,000 detained in Kazakhstan over violent protests
news_article: Nearly 10,000 people in Kazakhstan were detained by security forces during the violent anti-government protests last week, the Interior Ministry said. "A substantial number of foreign nationals" were among the detainees, officials said. Kazakhstan's President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev had said the protests, in which at least 164 people were killed, were instigated by "terrorists" with foreign backing.

news_headline: Philippines sees record high daily COVID-19 cases for 3rd straight day
news_article: The Philippines reported 33,169 new COVID-19 cases on Monday, logging a record high caseload for the third straight day. The authorities added that 145 deaths were confirmed taking the death toll to over 50,000. However, the existing restrictions allowing restaurants, gyms to operate at 30% capacity will remain. The country reported 26,458 and 28,707 cases on Saturday and Sunday respectively.

news_headline: Sudan pro-democracy group rejects UN offer for talks with military
news_article: Sudan's leading pro-democracy group, the Sudanese Professionals' Association (SPA) rejected UN's offer to mediate talks with the military. SPA said that the "only way" out of the ongoing crisis is through the removal of the generals from power. The group reiterated its demand for a fully civilian government. Sudan plunged into crisis after a military coup in October last year.

news_headline: China offers Kazakhstan support to deter 'external forces' amid riots
news_article: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi on Monday said that China is willing to support Kazakhstan maintain stability amid anti-government protests. Wang, who spoke to Kazakh Deputy PM, said Beijing can increase "law enforcement and security cooperation" with Kazakhstan and help the country oppose interference by "external forces". Riots triggered by a fuel price hike broke out last week in Kazakhstan.
